summary.p: [1] In haste. The situation [in Konstanz] is good. The people of Konstanz should just be brave! In eight days, a diet will take place in Baden. In the meantime, the people of Zürich are negotiating with the three [Protestant] cantons. As soon as Georg [Müller] has returned [from the meeting with Konrad Zwick], further steps will be discussed. Everyone shows determination. However, one should trust in God and not in man and submit to the cross, whether victory or defeat comes. One should pray to God!

[2] In Bern, things are going very well. The people of Bern want to put an end to the [Eucharist] dispute and are once again in agreement with the people of Zürich. They adhere to their disputation [of 1528] and expel from the country anyone who does not comply.
[3] Bullinger wishes for information on the situation in Augsburg.
[4] [P.S.:] Today, two hours before daybreak, a council meeting was held.

div.p: Greetings. In great haste. The situation is good. Be brave and courageous! God will not abandon us! In eight days, a general assembly will take place in Baden. In the meantime, my lords are negotiating with the three cantons separately. When Master Georg returns, we will see what further actions to take. Praise be to God! Everyone is determined. However, we should only look to God, not to man, and submit ourselves to the cross, whether we are victorious or defeated. Let us pray to God faithfully and earnestly! God be with you and all of yours.

In Bern, things are going very well. They want to end the dispute over the sacrament. They have been in agreement with us from the beginning. They are once again looking to disputation. Those who oppose it are sent out of the country. God be eternally with us!
Ah, how are things in Augsburg? I am very concerned! Sunday, January 2nd, at the ninth hour in the morning, 1547.
Today, a council meeting was held two hours before daybreak. Bullinger.
To his beloved and friendly lord and brother, Master Ambrosius Blarer, preacher in Konstanz.
